description: From Middle English tiklen, tikelen, of uncertain origin. Perhaps from a frequentative form of Middle English tikken (“to touch lightly”), thus equivalent to tick +‎ -le; or perhaps related to Old English tinclian (“to tickle”). Compare North Frisian tigele (“to tickle”) (Hallig dialect), and tiikle (“to tickle”) (Amrum dialect), German dialectal zicklen (“to excite; stir up”). Alternatively, compare Middle English kitlelen ("to tickle"; see kittle), of which tickle might ultimately be a metathetic alteration.

adjectives.description: tickle (comparative more tickle, superlative most tickle)

entries.meaning: An itchy feeling resembling the result of tickling.
examples: I have a persistent tickle in my throat.

entries.meaning: (cricket, informal) A light tap of the ball.

examples: Cow Head itself is a prominent headland connected to the settlement by a natural causeway, or ‘tickle’ as the Newfoundlanders prefer it.

verbs.description: tickle (third-person singular simple present tickles, present participle tickling, simple past and past participle tickled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To touch repeatedly or stroke delicately in a manner which causes laughter, pleasure and twitching.
examples: He tickled Nancy's tummy, and she started to giggle.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To unexpectedly touch or stroke delicately in a manner which causes displeasure or withdrawal.
examples: A stranger tickled Nancy's tummy, causing her to scream in fear.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a body part) To feel as if the body part in question is being tickled.
examples: My nose tickles, and I'm going to sneeze!

entries.meaning: (transitive) To appeal to someone's taste, curiosity etc.
(transitive) To cause delight or amusement in.
examples: He was tickled to receive such a wonderful gift.
He with secret joy thereforeDid tickle inwardly in every vein.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To catch fish in the hand (usually in rivers or smaller streams) by manually stimulating the fins.
